channel.title: Linkity Link
channel.description: A curated collection of interesting links by Brad Barrish

item.title: The music industry is building the tech to hunt down AI songs
item.description: With no way to stop the onslaught of AI music, the industry is taking a different approach: figuring out how to make money off of it.

item.title: Using AI Right Now: A Quick Guide
item.description: Which AIs to use, and how to use them, according to Ethan Mollick

item.title: Apple Updates Its On-Device and Cloud AI Models, Introduces a New Developer API
item.description: Apple revamped two vision-language models in a bid to play catch-up

item.title: Smoking Tigers (Original Score) by Masayoshi Fujita
item.description: Chill with some beautiful Masayoshi Fujita ambient music.

item.title: 28 Years Later (Original Motion Picture Soundtrack) by Young Fathers
item.description: I know absolutely nothing about these films, but I'm a big Young Fathers fan and this is a great soundtrack.

item.title: The Real Artificial Intelligence Challenge for Museums Isn’t Tech, It’s Time
item.description: Artificial intelligence may redefine museums—not through tech alone, but through creativity and purpose!

item.title: Objects from the future
item.description: Objects from the Future is a tool for encouraging creative thinking about the future, adapted from imagination card game, The Thing from the Future.

item.title: One Minute Park
item.description: Touch some grass... on your screen.

item.title: Breakthrough cancer test predicts whether chemotherapy will work
item.description: The test was developed by University of Cambridge and looks at structure of tumour DNA to forecast whether it will resist treatment. #fuckcancer

item.title: VSCO Debuts Standalone iPhone Camera App With Popular Photo Filters
item.description: Looks like VSCO is getting in on the standalone camera app action. My current favorite is !Camera. Halide is a close second.

item.title: YES PLZ COFFEE
item.description: Not an ad! My daily drink, main squeeze coffee subscription. 5-stars. Would recommend.

item.title: The radical idea that space-time remembers could upend cosmology
item.description: There are new hints that the fabric of space-time may be made of "memory cells" that record the whole history of the universe. If true, I have no idea what it means, but COOL!

item.title: A Letter From An Iranian
item.description: An important perspective. The writer's family is in Tehran. Here's what this war means to them.

item.title: The Computer-Science Bubble Is Bursting
item.description: Artificial intelligence is ideally suited to replacing the very type of person who built it.

item.title: How not to lose your job to AI
item.description: While AI drives down the value of skills it can do, it drives up the value of skills it can't— because they become the bottlenecks to further automation (for a while at least).

item.title: Project Indigo - a computational photography camera app from Adobe Labs
item.description: I installed the app on my iPhone 16 Pro this weekend with nice results

item.title: Creative Commons 4.0 has arrived on Flickr!
item.description: Nice to see Flickr (yes, it still exists) implementing Creative Commons 4.0 to improve licensing, sharing, collaborating, and attribution.

item.title: Nxtscape
item.description: Yet another agentic browser claiming to be focused on privacy.

item.title: Harper: Free, Open Source Grammar Checker
item.description: Harper checks your writing fast, without compromising your privacy. It runs on-device. Seems like this could be a good alternative to Grammarly.

item.title: No more Mr. Nice Guy: The incomparable Michael Bierut steps down
item.description: Design legend retires at 67 with SHOCKING confession: "I felt like a fraud".

item.title: phone noise
item.description: EXPOSED: Your phone is turning you into a DEMON-POSSESSED zombie (artist REVEALS the terrifying truth)

item.title: The Lipstick Index is cooked
item.description: ECONOMISTS PANIC as $1 billion beauty theory DIES - here's what replaced it (and it's EVERYWHERE)

item.title: The OpenAI Files
item.description: BOMBSHELL leaked files EXPOSE OpenAI's $300 billion betrayal - employees reveal SHOCKING truth about Sam Altman

item.title: Notes on Managing ADHD
item.description: Strategies and tactics for staying productive.

item.title: The Anti-Autocracy Handbook: A Scholars' Guide to Navigating Democratic Backsliding
item.description: Top scholars release emergency handbook revealing how autocrats destroy universities and what academics must do to survive.

item.title: The Biggest Companies Across America Are Cutting Their Workforces - W…
ChatGPT's Impact On Our Brains According to an MIT Study
item.description: The study, from MIT Lab scholars, measured the brain activity of subjects writing SAT essays with and without ChatGPT.

item.title: No the 16 billion credentials leak is not a new data breach
item.description: News broke today of a "mother of all breaches," sparking wide media coverage filled with warnings and fear-mongering. However, it appears to be a compilation of previously leaked credentials stolen by infostealers, exposed in data breaches, and via credential stuffing attacks.

item.title: What Is a ‘Fridge Cigarette’? A New Term for Diet Coke Gains Traction…
item.description: Gen Z workers are calling Diet Coke "fridge cigarettes" - and it's changing workplace breaks forever

item.title: Researchers develop and validate tool to identify strengths in students as young as preschool
item.description: The fields of education, psychology, social welfare and others have increasingly focused on a person's strengths to help them succeed. But the effort has overlooked the youngest students.

item.title: What if the key to better business was… less?
item.description: Lucie Montel writes this guest post sharing a degrowth philosophy for business

item.title: DREAM RECORDER — DREAM OUT LOUD
item.description: Dream Recorder is a portal to your subconscious. The magical bedside device catches your nightly visions and plays them back as vivid, cinematic reels. WTAF?

item.title: The ‘attention equation’: Winning the right battles for consumer attention
item.description: McKinsey’s new “attention equation” sheds new light on consumer attention spans and explores how today’s brands can reach consumers more effectively.

item.title: AI is poised to rewrite history. Literally.
item.description: The technology’s ability to read and summarize text is already making it a useful tool for scholarship. How will it change the stories we tell about the past?

item.title: Clipse - So Be It (Official Music Video)
item.description: From the new album 'Let God Sort Em Out', coming on July 11

item.title: How Field Notes went from side project to cult notebook
item.description: Two decades after Aaron Draplin and Jim Coudal launched Field Notes, the analog notebook company is crushing it in the digital age.

item.title: Doctors Say You Can Go Ahead and Slap a Nicotine Patch on for Some Extra Focus
item.description: People who struggle with concentration can, according to some doctors, have a nicotine patch or piece of gum as a treat.

item.title: Will New York Soon Make It Too Easy to Die?
item.description: Eleven states have legalized assisted dying, but only New York would have no waiting period, which risks turning suicide into a medical treatment option.

item.title: How to draft a will to avoid becoming an AI ghost—it’s not easy
item.description: Why requests for “no AI resurrections” will probably go ignored.

item.title: Seven replies to the viral Apple reasoning paper – and why they fall short
item.description: Gary Marcus destroys 7 desperate attempts to defend the viral Apple study - here's why Big Tech is panicking

item.title: Why We Want Robots at Work but Humans in Art
item.description: We hate other people when latency becomes intolerable. As soon as a task is about speed, other humans feel like an irritating inconvenience.

item.title: It matters. I care.
item.description: When we throw up our hands and say none of it matters, we're doing the fascists’ work for them. They don't need to hide their corruption if they can convince us it's pointless to look. They don't need to silence truth-tellers if we've already decided truth is meaningless.

item.title: A receipt printer cured my procrastination [ADHD]
item.description: This weird $150 printer trick cured 20 years of procrastination using video game psychology
